question: Position error is caused due to
explanation:
•  Position error is the difference between the actual static pressure and the pressure sensed by the aircraft’s static system, mainly due to airflow disturbances.

  • Causes:

    • Forward Motion: Creates suction at the static port, slightly lowering sensed pressure compared to when stationary.

    • Turbulent Airflow: Increases error, especially near the pitot/static heads.

    • Angle of Attack: At higher angles (typically at lower speeds), the static port may be misaligned with the airstream, increasing error.

    • Flap Settings: Flight manuals may list position error values that vary with flap configuration.

    • Pressure Head Design & Location: Affects how accurately static pressure is sensed.

  • Effect on Pitot vs Static:

    • Turbulence behind the pitot opening doesn’t affect pitot pressure much, but it does impact the static pressure due to disturbed airflow around the static ports.
subject: Navigation

question: What will happen if an a/c has 2 altimeters, one of which is compensated for position error, whilst the other is not:

choices.choice: One will over read at high air speed
One will under read at high air speed
One will under read close to the ground

explanation:
Position (or Pressure) Error

  • Caused by the aircraft’s disturbance of the airflow, meaning the static ports don’t sense the true ambient static pressure.
  • The error is generally small at low speeds, but increases as:
    • Mach number increases (high-speed flight)
    • Altitude increases (because high altitudes usually mean high Mach cruise)
  • At high Mach numbers, the static pressure sensed can be lower than actual — causing the altimeter to overread (shows higher altitude than real).
subject: Navigation
